issue.title: Adding an interface to hmmlearn within sktime!

repository.name: hmmlearn
repository.description: Hidden Markov Models in Python, with scikit-learn like API

issue.body:
Hello! 

Just wanted to let you know that the team over at sktime really likes this package and we are in the progress of writing an interface within [sktime](https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/) to facilitate use of this package for time series annotation! 

This issue is basically just to give you a heads up/keep you in the loop (ie no action needed on your part unless you have an issue with the plan)!  I will update this issue when we have something ready to be merged so you can also take a look at it if you want.

Thank you for putting this package together! :)

body: Hi! Since no one else has taken over, I am planning to work on importing these estimators this weekend, after a paper deadline tomorrow!
Fantastic, thank you! :D  Let me know if you have any questions on this and I would be happy to review your PR when its ready, just ping me

issue.title: [ENH] Imports wrapped CategoricalHMM estimator

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->

Part of https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3363


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

This PR adds a wrapper around CategoricalHMM

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->
Yes, this PR uses hmmlearn as a soft dependency.

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->
I noticed a type in the setup.cfg file that was not allowing me to run the parametrized pytest. Fixing the typo, I was able to succesfully run them.

<!--
#### PR checklist

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [ ] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.



Thanks for contributing!
-->

body:
So I think myself and a few co-workers are also going to work on this issue.  Seeing that issue #3597 was never resolved, and there does not seem to be any additional HMM modules imported into the library since this issue, we're planning on seeing if we can get some of these taken care of.  

Please let us know if there are any recommendations about how best to proceed.

I would recommend starting with the HMM modules other than `CategoricalHMM` at the moment (as @kejsitake still has a draft PR open on that at the moment). Please ping me when you get a PR together! :)

Thank you!  We are working on the PoissonHMM right now, and if that goes well we'll do the MultinomialHMM too.  We're planning on attending the dev-standup tomorrow if we need help and get the PR taken care of ASAP.

@miraep8 We are working on multinomial & poisson right now, but had a question about unit tests.  Right now the unit tests use a function called `piecewise_normal`, would it be sufficient to use this for unit tests for MultinomialHMM & PoissonHMM's too, or is it preferred we create the corresponding functions `piecewise_multinomial` and `piecewise_poisson` and use that for the datagen?  Thank you!

I think the question with unit tests is always - what are you actually trying to test? :)  For example - are you interested in how these HMM's fit a piecewise normal data set, in that case then yes!  But I suspect you might be more interested in - how well do these HMM's fit the data they are trying to describe (which in this case would be a `piecewise_poisson` as you suggested!)

If going down that route - here would be my suggestion: 

- make a separate branch/PR for those new data gen functions you described!  Then once that is merged you can make the PRs for `PossionHMM` and `MultinomialHMM`.  Of course feel free to ping me when you make that PR.

Cheers!

Thanks, appreciated.  Question:  I'm looking through the `tests` folder and don't see anything specifically for the `datagen` functions.  Is there a place where we should add a unit test for the functions mentioned above?

@miraep8 We have just submitted a PR for the piecewise_poisson as you suggested. #4078

Thank you.

issue.title: [ENH] added piecewise_multinomial function to datagen.py

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
PR #3363 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
In order to complete the unit tests for importing different modules in HMMLearn, additional data generation functions needed to be written for the appropriate modules.  This pull requests added a function called `piecewise_multinomial` that generates multinomial data to be used in unit tests.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
Making sure the random number generation works in a way that's compatible with the way HMMLearn will ingest it.

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ X] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

body: Nice work!  And I think you all actually suggested it not me! :)  Will check it out now, and thanks a lot for your help getting these estimators ported!

Oh also - to answer your question - sure tests are always a good idea! :) We very well might not have them for the existing datagen functions, but that shouldn't stop you from adding some for your own!  I think the most logical place to put this would be sktime -> annotation -> tests and then make a new file called `test_datagen.py`.  Thank you for spotting this!

One other alternative to add a quick test (if you just want to see that the code can be imported and generate the results you expect) is to just use the docs tests. I see that you both skipped the docs tests in your PRs, which is also what `piecewise_normal` does, so not necessarily bad! (although I actually forget why we skip the docs test there, perhaps @lmmentel can remind me?).  To see an example that doesn't skip the docs tests can check out the `piecewise_normal_multivariate` instead.

Thanks for picking up the work @JonathanBechtel and @Pyyim! I don't recall exactly what was the issue with doctests but probably reproducing random samples and/or getting consistent predictions based on those. At this point if you add a test that checks if the dimensions of the produced samples are OK it will already be an improvement on top of what's there.
